moves.2. d4: White initiates the Sicilian Smith-Mora Gambit
moves.3. Qxd4: And white has had enough of proper openings
moves.3... Nc6: This move attacks the queen, forcing white to retreat and gains me a tempo (clearly no one ever told white that it is not a good idea to win a pawn with your queen)
moves.4. Qd1 e5 5. Bd3: White decides to active his bishop, I don't suppose there is anything wrong with this more, personally I would have played Nf4
moves.5... Nf6: Looking at this now I like Bb4+, but in this game I decided to go for a more solid Nf6.
moves.6. Nf3: White seems to have the same sort of idea in mind.  I'm thinking if I where him I might consider a late game ruy-lopez sort of thing (is this a good idea?)
moves.6... Bc5: I am fairly fond of this formation, Ng4 from here seems to catch people off guard, however now that I'm playing in the 1300's this may no longer work so well.
moves.7. O-O: And my pretty little plan is shot.
moves.7... d5 8. Nc3 d4 9. Ne2 Nb4: What was I doing you ask, well blundering of course.  I think over confidence had something to do with it.
moves.10... O-O: I go for king saftey and beging wondering how on earth I can recover, e5 being a pretty important part of my game.
moves.14... Rad8 15. Qe3: I think this move by white was the only thing that gave me a bit of breathing room, allowing me a little bit of tempo.
moves.20. e5 Qe6 21. Qf3: I think it was here that I started to see my only chance, and decided to go for it full throttle.  When I am behind like this I like to throw everything I have at one attack, and hope it work out, Kamikaze style.
moves.21... Rd7 22. Rfe1 b6 23. cxb6: If white had played c6 here I would have been toast.
moves.23... Rxd6: Will he take it I'm wondering?
